metadata.case_name: Decree-Holder Co-operative Credit Society v. Raja Nandlal

facts.text: Raja Nandlal was a member of the decree-holder Society and was also its debtor.
A dispute arose between Raja Nandlal and the society and under the rules governing such societies the matter was referred to arbitration.

The arbitrator on the 19th Meher 1352 F., passed a decree against Raja Nandlal in the sum of Rs. 8,100 payable in equal six monthly instalments with six per cent. interest, the first instalment being payable at the end of Azur 1353 F.

On the 2nd Dai 1353 F., under the provisions of section 42, clause d, of the Co-operative Societies Act the decree was sent for execution to the civil court on a certificate issued under the signature of one Moulvi Mohammed Hasan, Madadgar Nazim. The amount recoverable was stated as Rs. 8,100 principal and Rs. 666-9-0 interest.

On the same day the decree-holder presented an application for execution of the decree to the Civil Court, Balda, claiming recovery of Rs. 10,339-14-9. It was alleged that as default had been committed in the payment of the first instalment due in the month of Azur 1353 F., the whole decretal amount had become recoverable. It was prayed that the property detailed in the application be attached.

On 3rd Dai 1353 F., i.e., a day after the presentation of the application for execution, the judgment debtor deposited a sum of Rs. 1,000 towards the first instalment in the Office of the Registrar of Co-operative Societies and expressed his willingness to deposit any further amount that may be due towards that instalment.
The Nazims office stated in reply that as he had committed default in the payment of the first instalment the whole decree had become due and the amount of Rs. 1,000 could not be accepted.

Subsequently, however, on the 5th Dai 1353 F., a letter was issued by one Mohammed Aihsan, Assistant Madadgar Nazim, to the Civil Court, Balda, saying that Rs. 1,034 had been deposited in the Office of the Nizamat Co-operative Credit Societies and therefore the proceedings in execution should be stayed or adjourned.
On receipt of the letter in the civil court the decree-holder raised an objection that the Registrar had no jurisdiction to stay execution of the decree as he was not an executing court.

This objection was overruled by the court and it was held that under the provisions of section 42 of the Co-operative Credit Societies Act the Registrar retained the power of staying execution of the award decree even after the issue of a certificate by him. In the result the execution proceedings were stayed.

Against this order an appeal was taken to the Sadar Adalat. The Sadar Adalat allowed the appeal partially and held that to the extent of the payment made the decree could not be executed but it could be executed with respect to future instalments as and when they would fall due. It further found that the default clause in the decree must be taken to have been condoned by the deposit of the first instalment in the office of the Registrar.

The decree-holder preferred a second appeal to the High Court but without any material success. The High Court held that there had been a default in the payment of the first instalment and the decree-holder had thus a right to execute the whole decree and that neither the Registrar nor the executing court could deprive the decree-holder of that right.
In spite of this finding it took the view that the Registrar still retained jurisdiction to adjourn execution proceedings.

The contention of the judgment-debtor that the certificate was bad as having been issued by a Madadgar Nazim was negatived. It was held that the Madadgar Nazim had delegated powers in this respect and that the defect, if any, stood cured by a fresh certificate signed by the Nazim himself.
The result was that with these findings the decision of the executing court adjourning the execution proceedings was maintained.
A fresh certificate was issued by the Nazim in order to cure a defect that might be said to exist in the original certificate because of its having been sent by the Madadgar Nazim.

legal_issues.text: Jurisdiction of the Registrar functioning under the Co-operative Credit Societies Act in respect to execution of decrees, particularly whether the Registrar can intervene during execution proceedings pending in a civil court on the basis of the certificate granted by him, accept payments, or stay execution.
Interpretation of section 42, clause d, of the Co-operative Credit Societies Act, 1340 F., as amended.
Whether the default in payment of the first instalment was condoned by the deposit in the Registrar's office.
Validity of the original certificate issued by Madadgar Nazim.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Registrar had no jurisdiction to stay execution of the decree as he was not an executing court.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 42, clause d, Co-operative Credit Societies Act

respondent_arguments.text: The certificate was bad as having been issued by a Madadgar Nazim.

court_reasoning.text: The language employed in section 42, clause d, does not place the Registrar on the same pedestal as a court passing the decree under the Civil Procedure Code. The Registrar has the capacity of the court passing the decree but not of the executing court. The only jurisdiction conferred on the Registrar is to issue a certificate and send the decree for execution to civil court or revenue court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Registrar cannot be constituted an executing court or conferred powers in the matter of execution.

court_reasoning.text: After issuing a certificate, the Registrar may cancel it or withdraw execution from one court to another, but on the plain words of the section, he has no powers in execution proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The act of the Registrar in accepting the first instalment was a clear trespass on the duties of the executing court.

court_reasoning.text: Payment towards satisfaction of the decree could only be made in the executing court, as Registrar lacks jurisdiction to execute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requisition of the Registrar to stop execution and acceptance of instalment were in excess of jurisdiction and could be ignored by executing court.

court_reasoning.text: The Registrar could not alter or amend the decree passed by the Arbitrator at this stage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analogy of Civil Procedure Code not applicable, as Registrar has no jurisdiction to execute his own decree.

court_reasoning.text: High Court decision contradictory: found default not condoned, whole decree executable, but still allowed Registrar to stay proceedings.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act of Registrar in asking civil court to stay is encroachment on powers of executing court.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to consider invalidity of original certificate as fresh certificate issued by Nazim cures any defect.

holdings.text: Registrar under section 42(d) has no jurisdiction to execute, accept payments, stay, or intervene in execution proceedings in civil court after issuing certificate.
Executing court entitled to ignore Registrar's requisitions exceeding jurisdiction.
Default not condoned; decree-holder entitled to execute whole amount.

statutes_cited.name: Co-operative Credit Societies Act, 1340 F.
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs enforcement of award by Registrar through certificate to civil or revenue court; Registrar not executing court

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Distinguished; court passing decree retains execution jurisdiction even if transferred, unlike Registrar

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, decisions of all three courts below set aside, executing court directed to proceed with execution of the decree from the stage at which it was interfered with by the letter from Registrar's office.
outcome.relief_granted: Execution proceedings to proceed for full decretal amount.

key_quotes.text: The only jurisdiction conferred on the Registrar is that he can issue a certificate and on that certificate he can send a decree either to the civil court or to a revenue officer.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines limited role of Registrar under s42(d)

key_quotes.text: The act of the Registrar in accepting the first instalment was a clear trespass on the duties of the executing court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The act of the Registrar in asking the civil court to stay execution proceedings pending before it is a clear encroachment on the powers of the executing court and is in excess of his statutory powers and should have been ignored by the courts.
key_quotes.speaker: court
